nl.marcvanzee.KEProver.prover
Class SAKE

java.lang.Object
  nl.marcvanzee.KEProver.prover.SAKE

public class SAKE
extends java.lang.Object

The Prover, the beast behind all the glitter and glamour.
A SAKE implementation of a propositional logic tableau prover.

Author:
marc

private  java.lang.String alphaReductions()
          tries to find possible alpha reductions in the current formula.
Uses the method alphaReduce(Subformula subformula, int type) for the hard work.

The following formulas are applicable to alpha reductions:
(0) -(p>q) <=> p,-q right->
(1) -(p|q) <=> -p,-q right-|
(2) p&q <=> p,q left-&
private  java.lang.String betaReductions()
          tries to find possible beta reductions in the current formula.

The following formulas are applicable to alpha reductions:
(0) -(p&q) & p |- -q right1-&
(1) -(p&q) & q |- -p right2-&
(2) p|q & -p |- q left1-|
(3) p|q & -q |- q left2-|
(4) p>q & p |- q left1->
(5) p>q & -q |- -p left2->
private  java.lang.String betaSubsumptions()
          tries to find possible beta subsumptions in the current formula.

the following formulas are applicable to beta subsumptions:
(0) p|q & p => remove p|q
(1) p|q & q => remove p|q
(2) p&p & p => remove p&p
(3) p>p & p => remove p>p
(4) p

remove p
private  Subformula DC()
          looks for a possibility for DC, using the heuristic suggested by Jeremey Pitt
and Jim Cunningham, namely to select the least complex sub-formula of the
most complex formula.

finds one of these formulas
(0) -(P&Q), without P, Q
(1) P|Q, without -P, -Q
(2) P>Q, without P, -Q
(3) P=Q, without P, Q, -P, -Q

private  java.lang.String reduce()
          all the reductions are called from here, in the following order:
- removeNegations(): looks for double negations;
- removeDoubles(): remove double appearances of subformulas;
- betaSubsumption();
- etaReductions();
- betaReductions();
- alphaReductions();

note that when any of the methods returns a value, this value
is immediately returned and no other methods is called.

Method Detail

isProvable

public boolean isProvable()
the actual proving of the formula.

Goes through the following steps:
1. check for a contradiction and try to reduce the formula by calling the reductions() method
2. if there is a contradiction, return true
3. repeat (1,2) until there are no more reductions possible
4. try dc by calling the DC() method
5. if DC() does not succeed, stop and print a countermodel
6. if DC() succeeds, create two branches, add the DC formula and call this method recursively
7. if one of the branches does not close, return false
8. if both the branches close, return true

During this process, a ProofBranch object is used to keep track of the steps

Returns:
true if the formula is provable, false otherwise.

reduce

private java.lang.String reduce()
all the reductions are called from here, in the following order:
- removeNegations(): looks for double negations;
- removeDoubles(): remove double appearances of subformulas;
- betaSubsumption();
- etaReductions();
- betaReductions();
- alphaReductions();

note that when any of the methods returns a value, this value
is immediately returned and no other methods is called.

Returns:
reduction description. if no reductions is possible, null is returned

DC

private Subformula DC()
looks for a possibility for DC, using the heuristic suggested by Jeremey Pitt
and Jim Cunningham, namely to select the least complex sub-formula of the
most complex formula.

finds one of these formulas
(0) -(P&Q), without P, Q
(1) P|Q, without -P, -Q
(2) P>Q, without P, -Q
(3) P=Q, without P, Q, -P, -Q

Returns:
a Subformula object to spit on, or null when none found.

removeDoubles

protected java.lang.String removeDoubles()
search formula for double occurrences and remove if found.

Returns:
a description of the double occurrence reduction, or null when none is possible

removeNegations

protected java.lang.String removeNegations()
search formula for double negations and remove if found.

Returns:
a description of the negation reduction, or null when none is possible

alphaReductions

private java.lang.String alphaReductions()
tries to find possible alpha reductions in the current formula.
Uses the method alphaReduce(Subformula subformula, int type) for the hard work.

The following formulas are applicable to alpha reductions:
(0) -(p>q) <=> p,-q right->
(1) -(p|q) <=> -p,-q right-|
(2) p&q <=> p,q left-&

Returns:
a description of the alpha reduction, or null when none is possible

alphaReduce

private boolean alphaReduce(Subformula subformula,
                            int type)
used by alphaReductions().

Parameters:
subformula - the subformula to perform alpha reduction on
type - the kind of reduction, see alphReductions() description for a list
Returns:
true if the alpha reductions has succeeded, else false.

betaReductions

private java.lang.String betaReductions()
tries to find possible beta reductions in the current formula.

The following formulas are applicable to alpha reductions:
(0) -(p&q) & p |- -q right1-&
(1) -(p&q) & q |- -p right2-&
(2) p|q & -p |- q left1-|
(3) p|q & -q |- q left2-|
(4) p>q & p |- q left1->
(5) p>q & -q |- -p left2->

Returns:
a description of the beta reduction, or null when none is possible

betaSubsumptions

private java.lang.String betaSubsumptions()
tries to find possible beta subsumptions in the current formula.

the following formulas are applicable to beta subsumptions:
(0) p|q & p => remove p|q
(1) p|q & q => remove p|q
(2) p&p & p => remove p&p
(3) p>p & p => remove p>p
(4) p

remove p

Returns:
a description of the beta subsumptions, or null when none is possible

etaReductions

private java.lang.String etaReductions()
tries to find possible eta reductions in the current formula.
Uses the method etaReduce(Subformula subformula, int type) for the hard work.

The following formulas are applicable to eta reductions:
(0) p & -(p
(1) q & -(p
(2) -p & -(p
(3) -q & -(p
(4) p & p
(5) q & p
(6) -p & p
(7) -q & p

Returns:
a description of the eta reduction, or null when none is possible

Returns:
